report_title: Employment & Recruiting Agencies in the US
executive_summary: The Employment and Recruiting Agencies industry places job-seekers in available positions, taking commissions from client businesses that seek capable employees. Despite a collapsing labor market in 2020, employment agency revenue expanded at a CAGR of 11.7% in the past five years, including 0.3% growth to reach $46.7 billion in 2023. Additionally, the transition to online work lowers costs and supports profit growth through 2023. Revenue growth was fueled by a 52.0% rise in 2021 alone, as the labor shortage, shift to remote work and economic recovery sparked a surge in demand for employment and recruitment agencies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pandemic disruptions have continued to shape the industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 turned the labor market upside down. Companies laid off millions in 2020, then ramped up hiring in 2021. The labor market remains extremely tight. 2020 shocks to labor markets created a shortage of workers as the participation rate stagnated. Companies couldn't find workers to fill positions. Wage hikes haven't quite solved the problem, though hiring pressure has eased. Companies have turned to hiring agencies to help fill recruitment gaps, leading to higher employment and recruiting agency revenue in 2021 and 2022. Revenue surged in 2021, rising 52.0%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A dynamic labor market drives volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Work from home broadens the scope of employment and recruiting agencies. Agencies don't need to focus only on certain regions. A remote worker in New York is a viable candidate for a hiring company in California. Wage costs have contributed to spiking inflation. To smother the fire, the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates in 2022. Rates remain elevated in 2023, limiting new hires and demand for employment and recruiting agency services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Markets embrace long term digital trends
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Online job boards have gained market share. Recruiting is less personal and tailored. Companies post jobs on hiring websites with great success. Agencies can post job openings on multiple job boards with a single click, rather than having to create and post individual job postings on each website. Social media enables small businesses to reach out directly to potential workers. Local social networks can replace Agencies and job boards. A Facebook post is cheaper and can reach thousands of potential hires.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Productivity concerns put agencies at risk
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Labor productivity fell in 2022, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Many workers report feeling burnt out and unmotivated. Wages climbed over the same period. Clients notice poorly performing hires recommended by employment and recruiting agencies. Poor worker performance weighs on agencies' reputations. The Great Resignation, which began in 2021, is continuing in 2023. Millions of workers are leaving their jobs in search of better opportunities, like higher salaries, better benefits, and more flexibility. This is putting a strain on employers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: After beginning to rise in March 2022, the Federal Reserve is likely to lower interest rates in the next five years. However, higher rates at the start of the five years to 2028 are likely to limit hiring early on. Companies will seek out temporary workers for short term projects. Lower economic activity discourages permanent hiring. Temporary agencies, not included in employment and recruiting agencies, have come under fire for paying workers below minimum wage in New Jersey. Employment and recruiting agencies could lose business from temporary agencies if costs rise.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition will likely rise for agencies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Online job postings from Indeed and LinkedIn take market share from employment and recruiting agencies. These sites' popularity will grow. Algorithms will match strong candidates to hiring companies. Employment and recruiting agencies will assess applicants on these websites. The sites make them more efficient while also offering a substitute to their services. Artificial intelligence is being used to automate many tasks that were previously performed by human recruiters. This is making it more efficient and cost-effective for employers to recruit candidates on their own.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifts to capital have mixed affects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Labor productivity has dipped in recent years. This accelerates the long term transition to capital use for many companies. Low paying labor jobs will hire less, hurting employment and recruiting agencies. Shifts to capital do not mean shifts away from human capital. Office workers' wages will rise in the next five years. Higher salary contracts earn more revenue for the employment and recruiting agencies that fill them. The healthcare sector is another sector that is expected to experience positive capital shifts over the next 5 years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The nature of work will likely change
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: One of the most significant changes is the rise of automation. Automation is already having a major impact on the workplace, and it is expected to continue to do so in the coming years. Another major change will be the increasing globalization of the workforce. Companies are increasingly hiring workers from all over the world, and they are also outsourcing tasks to other countries. This is creating new opportunities for workers, but it is also creating challenges. Demographic changes will also impact the nature of work.

industry_definition: This industry comprises establishments engaged in listing employment vacancies, referring job applicants to potential employers and assisting companies with employee recruitment and placement. Individuals referred or placed are not employees of the employment agencies.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Online job boards have made it easier for employers to find candidates and for candidates to find jobs. This has reduced the reliance on employment and recruitment agencies.
The employment and recruitment agencies industry is very fragmented, with many small and medium-sized businesses. This makes it difficult for any one agency to dominate the market.

The US is facing a labor shortage, with many employers struggling to find qualified workers. This has increased the demand for employment and recruiting agencies, as employers are turning to them to help them fill their open positions.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Construction, transportation and warehousing companies demand worker placement from employment and recruiting agencies. Labor shortages threatened these industries after 2020. Companies turned to employment and recruiting agencies for support, contributing to significant revenue growth. E-commerce and delivery expanded after 2020. Employment and recruiting agencies filled rosters for warehousing and transportation companies, particularly for temporary staff. The housing market's peak will limit construction worker demand. This weighs on employment and recruiting agencies' revenue in 2023.

Companies hiring managers rely on employment and recruiting agencies to vet candidates. High worker turnover and layoffs grew demand from this segment after 2020. Platforms like LinkedIn and Indeed enable employment and recruiting agencies to reach a wider candidate pool. Recruitment outsources to agencies for executive hiring is relatively uncommon compared with other markets. Internal human resource departments often manage hiring. Agencies don't fill these positions as quickly as other types of roles. These positions provide much higher revenue per job filled due to their more selective and time-consuming nature.

Human resources and clerical jobs grew after 2020. Remote work expanded the supply of HR workers. These departments still struggled with high turnover. Small businesses are increasingly outsourcing HR functions to HR professionals, as they do not have the resources to manage HR in-house. Payroll and management software accomplishes many human resources tasks. This threatens employment and recruiting agency revenue from this segment.

Placement for IT department jobs are in high demand. Most companies have expanded internet and technology infrastructures in recent years. Temporary workers make up a growing share of revenue from technical positions. Several factors contributed to layoffs in the tech sector from large companies, including overhiring during COVID-19, higher interest rates and pressure from investors to reduce expenses.

New healthcare jobs continue to pop up. Hospitals, clinics and private practices have grown in recent years. Temporary workers make up a large share of this market. Companies have raised concerns about temporary healthcare worker quality and productivity in recent years. Healthcare employers that provide flexible work schedules and various shift options will be better positioned to retain and attract top talent.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The national unemployment rate measures the proportion of Americans aged 16 or older who are currently unemployed and looking for work. A climbing unemployment rate represents declining demand from businesses for employees. When the unemployment rate rises it poses a potential threat to employment and recruitment agencies.

business_locations.location_description: Tourist destinations like Florida demand retail and service workers. Tourism's seasonal nature encourages temporary hiring. Agencies work to fill rosters for different clients throughout the year. Low taxes and rental costs have led to large warehousing and transportation hubs, like in Atlanta. Transportation and warehousing form a major market for employment and recruiting agencies.

New York and other major cities in the Mid-Atlantic provide high and low skilled employment. New York is a shipping, business and tourist hub. Transportation, warehousing, executive, temporary and service jobs form the backbone of its economy. Cities with diverse labor markets are a gold mine for employment and recruiting agencies. Agencies service a variety of clients and earn large contracts for high paying jobs.

California employs tourism related service and retail jobs. Entertainment related jobs give rise to a unique subset of employment and recruiting agencies. The state is home to a massive consumer market, ensuring transportation and warehousing jobs. Los Angeles has the largest port in the United States. Agricultural jobs provide seasonal revenue for temporary workers. Employment and recruiting agencies occasionally work to fill farm staff positions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: A license is required to operate as an employment agency in most states. The State Department of Labor issues licenses. In some states, any person who interviews, counsels or advises employers or employees on any matter related to employment and contracts needs a license. Licensing requirements can also affect the way that employment and recruitment agencies charge their clients for their services.

The federal CAN-SPAM Act, signed into law in 2003, regulates the use of e-mail as a form of communication and sets standards for sending mass e-mail messages. The law limits online recruitment sites' communication with clients and users. Agencies must clearly state and display their privacy policies and practices. The CAN-SPAM Act requires employment and recruitment agencies to provide job seekers with a way to unsubscribe from their email lists.

The American Staffing Association (ASA) has a general Code of Ethics and Good Practices and a code developed specifically for construction companies and day laborers. The code sets standards for member organizations, like treating applicants with respect, maintaining integrity, complying with laws and determining the qualifications of employees. The ASA supports its members' enforcement of and compliance with existing labor and employment regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The revenue volatility level is very high.
The industry assistance level is low and steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: Globalization level is low but increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Online job boards have made it easier for employers to find candidates and for candidates to find jobs, reducing reliance on employment and recruitment agencies.
The employment and recruitment agencies industry is very fragmented, with many small and medium-sized businesses, making it difficult for any one agency to dominate the market.

concentration_points.concentration_description: More clients lead to more market share. Employment and recruiting agencies specialize in different industries, clientele and job types.
The rapid digitization of online job listings and other services has enabled new players, like LinkedIn Corporation, to enter the industry and quickly capture a large market share.
Large recruiting agencies, like Randstad, have grown market share with mergers and acquisition activity.

cost_structure_breakdown.cost_type: Purchases of software, equipment and administrative items

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Price of Employment Data Dips After 2020
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry operators pay for storage to build databases of candidate information to reference. Purchase expenses may also include outsourced third-party functions, in addition to general office equipment. The considerable volume of employment data after 2020 pushed data prices down.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Legal Advice Helps Agencies With Contract Negotiations
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other expenses include insurance, selling, general and administrative expenses, legal expenses and more. Agencies invest in legal advice amid labor disputes and contract issues.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: MORE HIGHLY SKILLED WORKERS PUSHED WAGE SPENDING HIGHER
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Services are highly labor-intensive to manage relationships with corporate clients and job candidates. Companies use data warehousing and mining software to complete initial job screening tasks. Employees personally screen candidates. Wage expenditures spiked in response to client demand for employment and recruiting services. The shift to statistical-based matching caused an influx of higher-paid employees.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: ONLINE SERVICES BOOST PROFIT, BUT WEAK HIRING OUTLOOK REMAINS A THREAT
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some agencies specialize in placing skilled professionals, which typically generates a higher margin per placement than companies specializing in lower-skilled clerical, technical or manufacturing positions. Companies offering online services earn more profit than offline agencies because of lower operating costs. Wages have fallen as a share of revenue in the long run but spiked in the short run in response to labor shortages. Competitive pricing to obtain business during recessions erodes profit. Recession risks threaten agencies in 2023 and 2024. Hiring fell in 2020, limiting profit growth. Profit has recovered substantially following broad-based employment gains.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New agencies need staff to service clients and vet candidates. Analysts requiring high salaries can help develop matching and data mining methods.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Unemployment spiked in 2020, then fell in 2021 and 2022. Employment and recruiting agencies respond to demand for workers. If companies don't hire, agencies don't make money. Interest rate hikes will cause a brief dip in 2023 revenue. This trend exemplifies agencies' dependence on macroeconomic factors like interest rates and employment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Seasonal Dependence Has Its Perks and Risks
volatility_points.volatility_description: Temporary placement accounts for a significant share of revenue. Seasonal industries tend to use temporary workers for short-term operations. Agencies with permanent placement services receive consistent revenue. Seasonal dependence forces agencies to take advantage of small windows for solid sales growth.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SURVEYS AND REPORTS INFORM EMPLOYERS AND POTENTIAL EMPLOYEES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Agencies collect public survey data, which highlight labor market trends. Blog posts offer tips to find strong candidates, manage employees, succeed in job interviews and other aspects of the employer-employee relationship.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: The average staffing agency provides recruiting for a specific industry or line of business based on their in-depth knowledge of the industry.

FAQs.question: How do your marketing practices change during economic downturns?
FAQs.answer: During recessions, many players reduce expenditure on marketing efforts to curb spending.

FAQs.question: Does your company target a particular market segment or provide for a broad range of markets?
FAQs.answer: Employment and recruiting agencies are best able to adapt to a shifting economic landscape by serving an array of downstream markets, as some markets are less affected by economic downturns than others. However, players with strong connections to certain industries are best able to provide highly skilled employees who are best fit for their positions.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain relations with repeat or recurring customers during periods of declining demand?
FAQs.answer: By securing contracts to staff permanent employees regularly, agencies can mitigate some fluctuations in demand for the industry's services. Operational flexibility and a willingness to meet clients' shifting priorities on short notice help players maintain strong relations with their customers during periods of economic duress.

FAQs.question: Are web-based technologies, such as online document storage and video conferencing hurting your business?
FAQs.answer: The adoption of video conferencing and other web-based technologies has helped recruiting agencies increase their ability to interview candidates from anywhere.

FAQs.question: Does your company use screening and testing services to find qualified applicants for downstream markets?
FAQs.answer: Mobile applications have completely revolutionized how recruiting agencies look for qualified candidates because of their ability to reach candidates anywhere. Automated resume screening has become increasingly important and helped players streamline the process of reviewing prospective applicants.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure it is safeguarding your customers' information?
FAQs.answer: Agencies must ensure they meet the guidelines of various laws, including the CAN-SPAM Act, to provide the privacy and safety of their customers' private information.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain ethics and good practices?
FAQs.answer: The American Staffing Association (ASA) has a general Code of Ethics and Good Practices and a code developed specifically for construction companies and day laborers. The code sets standards for member organizations, such as respecting applicants, maintaining integrity, complying with laws and determining employees' qualifications.

FAQs.question: How do volatile economic conditions affect your company's profit?
FAQs.answer: Profit tends to decline during economic downturns as demand for the industry's services erodes. It grows during expansions as companies begin hiring again.

FAQs.question: How does seasonality affect your company's operations?
FAQs.answer: Many recruiting agencies provide workers in various fields to mitigate seasonality in any one field. Conversely, some players strategically serve markets that have differing seasonality to ensure demand for their services will remain steady.

FAQs.question: What is your budget for research and development? How easily can you adopt new technology? How do your capabilities compare with rivals' capabilities?
FAQs.answer: Keeping up to date with new technology, mainly using the internet portals for information on job vacancies and resume screening by employers, is vital for success in this industry. Advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning have reduced the labor intensity of the screening process, resulting in some workforce automation.

FAQs.question: How do you assure your clients that you will protect their privacy? What measures do you have in place to provide confidentiality to your clients?
FAQs.answer: It's important to ensure total confidentiality in all areas of operation and in all dealings with clients and potential placements. This factor is particularly important for executive search firms.

FAQs.question: Do you provide ongoing training for your employees?
How do you ensure you are hiring highly qualified employees?
FAQs.answer: Companies should hire talented and amiable workers who can seek out the best potential candidates for a job and negotiate effectively between clients (employers) and job candidates.

FAQs.question: How has your company competed with external competition for employment services?
FAQs.answer: Employment and recruiting agencies compete with companies that manage their own recruiting, often through online job portals and listings.

FAQs.question: Do you notice demand fluctuations when the number of businesses increases or decreases?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the number of businesses increases the need for new workers, which boosts demand for industry-relevant services, such as online job listings and candidate profiling.

FAQs.question: How do you market your services in times of low unemployment? How do your recruiting tactics differ? Do they change when unemployment increases?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the unemployment rate represents declining demand from businesses for employees and, therefore, reduces the number of placements available along with revenue for employment and recruiting agencies.
